policy_framework: Benin’s public procurement system is structured around Law No. 2020-26 of September 29, 2020, which provides the legal foundation for acquiring public goods and services, including health commodities. Oversight is provided by the National Directorate for Public Procurement Control (DNCMP), the Departmental Delegations for Public Procurement Control (DDCMP), and the Public Procurement Regulatory Authority (ARMP). In 2020, the government restructured its health commodity system by replacing CAME with SoBAPS S.A., expanding its mandate. Regulatory oversight is managed by ABREP through inspections and post-market surveillance. Health financing relies on government budgets, donor funding, and AM-ARCH, though sustainability remains uncertain. WAEMU MAPS regional frameworks also shape national procurement.
procurement_cycle: Benin’s procurement cycle is coordinated by the Ministry of Health, involving structured activities across several institutions. Need estimation uses PNDS and LMIS tools, but weak data systems hinder accuracy. Costing is managed through the Ministry of Health and ARCH scheme, though funding constraints reduce efficiency. Supplier selection is carried out by SoBAPS S.A. with ARMP oversight; limited planning and low procurement volumes affect bargaining power. Contract negotiation is conducted by SoBAPS under ARMP supervision. Purchase order creation faces frequent errors due to limited tracking systems. Reception of goods is handled by ABREP, though poor storage and training gaps affect stock management. Payment processing is supervised by the Ministry of Finance, but delays discourage supplier participation.
bottlenecks: Benin’s procurement system faces administrative delays, financial misalignment, and limited operational capacity. Weak coordination between the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Finance contributes to inefficiencies. Human resource shortages and emergency procurement practices bypass standard procedures. These issues cause frequent stockouts, delayed treatments, and weakened market leverage.
quality_assurance: Quality assurance is enforced by ABREP and ABMed through product testing, certification, and monitoring. Donor-supported systems such as WHO prequalification and batch testing complement national mechanisms. However, emergency procurement and limited regional QA infrastructure create risks. Stronger protocols and investment in regulatory systems are needed.
innovations: Benin has implemented several improvements including eLMIS/OpenLMIS pilots to improve stock visibility and reporting. Legal reforms under Law No. 2020-26 strengthened oversight and clarified emergency procurement. Donor-supported QA systems improved product integrity. Participatory budgeting initiatives have enhanced accountability and improved service delivery.

policy_framework: Guinea’s procurement system is grounded in the Code des Marchés Publics (Decree No. D/2012/128/PRG/SGG). The Ministry of Health leads sector policies, using a procurement manual for medical goods adopted in 2021. Oversight is provided by ARMP, while the Pharmacie Centrale de Guinée (PCG) manages procurement, storage, and distribution. Donor programs (e.g., World Bank) support procurement through electronic tools like STEP. Reforms aim to modernize PCG and increase domestic funding.
procurement_cycle: Guinea’s procurement cycle is jointly managed by the Ministry of Health and PCG SA. Need estimation uses facility-level data, though incomplete reporting limits accuracy. Costing is conducted with donor support but faces funding shortages and price volatility. Supplier selection is overseen by PCG SA with regulatory oversight; limited qualified suppliers and QA challenges persist. Contract negotiation faces delays and limited capacity. Purchase orders are managed by PCG SA but hampered by slow administrative processes. Goods reception is limited by storage capacity. Payment processing is delayed by currency fluctuations and weak financial controls.
bottlenecks: Guinea faces bottlenecks including incomplete reporting, limited human resources, slow administrative procedures, and weak institutional coordination. Root causes include underfunding, donor reliance, and outdated systems. These issues lead to stockouts, delayed access to treatment, and reduced purchasing power.
quality_assurance: Quality assurance is managed by PCG SA with Ministry of Health oversight. Inspection, supplier vetting, and post-market surveillance exist but suffer from infrastructure gaps and inadequate staffing. Donor-supported mechanisms (e.g., WHO prequalification) reduce risks, but emergency procurement still exposes vulnerabilities.
innovations: Guinea has implemented electronic inventory systems, standardized procurement procedures (2021 manual), and enhanced supplier accountability through donor partnerships. Modernization efforts of PCG aim to improve sustainability and transparency.

policy_framework: Niger’s procurement is governed by Public Procurement Act No. 2011-37 and Decree No. 2016-641. ONPPC oversees importation, storage, and distribution through ONPPC-EPIC, LANSPEX, and SONIPHAR. DPHL/MT regulates medicines and oversees licensing. Donor-funded programs for HIV, malaria, and TB are integrated into the system. Persistent challenges include weak logistics systems, delayed reporting, and reliance on external partners.
procurement_cycle: Niger’s procurement cycle involves DPHL/MT and ONPPC with support from donor programs. Need estimation uses facility consumption data validated by disease programs. Forecasting suffers from inconsistent reporting and limited capacity. Costing is carried out by DPHL/MT and ONPPC using supplier quotes but suffers from delayed budget approval. Supplier selection evaluates quality and price but is hampered by a limited vendor pool. Contract negotiation suffers from legal ambiguities and limited negotiation skills. Purchase order creation faces communication gaps. Goods reception includes quality control by LANSPEX. Payment processing is affected by bureaucracy and currency risks.
bottlenecks: Niger faces bottlenecks including weak logistics infrastructure, reporting delays, and limited technical capacity. Root causes include fragmented coordination, outdated systems, and insufficient investment. These challenges lead to stockouts and procurement delays.
quality_assurance: Quality assurance is led by LANSPEX with oversight from DPHL/MT. Testing and inspections ensure product safety, but limited equipment, substandard deliveries, and inadequate storage pose challenges. Strengthening lab capacity and warehouse infrastructure is needed.
innovations: Niger has improved procurement through ONPPC restructuring, Global Fund support, AMRH engagement, and LMIS introduction. Standardizing templates and automating payment processes reflect progress.

policy_framework: Mauritania’s procurement operates under Decree No. 2002-08 and Law No. 2010-044. The Central Procurement Board (CPB) manages procurement under Ministry of Health oversight. Persistent health system challenges include high infant mortality and low health spending. Development partners like the World Bank support reforms. Mauritania is a signatory to the Kigali Amendment, aligning health procurement with environmental goals.
procurement_cycle: Mauritania’s procurement cycle involves the Ministry of Health and CPB with partner support. Forecasting is conducted by disease programs (PNLS, PNLP, NTP) using surveys and health information systems. Costing is managed by the Ministry of Finance but affected by price fluctuations and donor dependence. Supplier selection uses WHO prequalified suppliers but is slowed by bureaucratic delays. Contract negotiation faces limited capacity and complex clauses. Purchase orders face errors and weak inventory systems. Goods reception is handled by Central Medical Stores but constrained by limited storage. Payment processing is hindered by delays, corruption risks, and donor reliance.
bottlenecks: Mauritania experiences bottlenecks including poor coordination, limited production capacity, bureaucratic delays, and reliance on donors. Root causes involve underinvestment, weak regulatory enforcement, and limited procurement expertise. These result in delivery delays and reduced access to essential medicines.
quality_assurance: Quality assurance is managed by the Quality Control Unit under the Ministry of Health. Verification occurs before distribution, but storage limitations and limited testing facilities weaken systems. Strengthening QA protocols, infrastructure, and staff training is needed.
innovations: Mauritania has improved procurement through CPB centralization, WHO and Global Fund collaboration, and efforts to digitize procurement and payment systems. Participation in global initiatives like the Kigali Amendment shows commitment to sustainable practices.

policy_framework: Senegal’s procurement system is governed by the Public Procurement Code (Decree No. 2022-2295), aligned with WAEMU standards. The Department of Pharmacy and Laboratories oversees pharmaceutical regulation, while PNA leads procurement, warehousing, and distribution. Partnerships with WHO and the Global Fund support product quality and availability. Challenges include bureaucratic delays, HR constraints, and gaps in financial monitoring.
procurement_cycle: Senegal’s procurement cycle involves MSAS, PNA, CNLS, and donor partners. Need estimation relies on health data, though inconsistent reporting undermines accuracy. Costing is managed using historical and donor data but suffers from delays due to misaligned donor cycles. Supplier selection is overseen by ARCOP, though limited supplier diversity affects timelines. Contract negotiation is handled by MSAS and PNA. Purchase orders are tracked through centralized systems but slowed by manual processes. Goods reception is supervised by multiple stakeholders, with LMIS used for logging. Payments are delayed due to slow reviews and donor timeline differences.
bottlenecks: Senegal faces bottlenecks including data gaps, administrative delays, limited supplier diversity, and manual processing systems. Root causes include under-resourced logistics, misaligned donor cycles, and fragmentation. These issues lead to stockouts and delayed access to medicines.
quality_assurance: Quality assurance is conducted through inspections by MSAS, PNA, and donor reps. LMIS logging supports QA, but limited warehouse staffing and manual verification compromise standards. Automation and capacity building are needed.
innovations: Senegal has made progress through WAEMU-aligned reforms, strong donor partnerships, centralized logistics systems, and LMIS adoption. Efforts to automate procurement and payments demonstrate commitment to sustainability.

policy_framework: Togo’s procurement framework is based on Decree No. 2022-080/PR and Law No. 2021-033. ARCOP regulates procurement. The Ministry of Health oversees procurement for HIV, malaria, and TB, supported by Global Fund mechanisms. CAMEG manages warehousing and distribution. Challenges include weak traceability, limited local drug production, and high out-of-pocket spending. AMU expansion has enrolled 800,000 people.
procurement_cycle: Togo’s procurement cycle involves the Ministry of Health and CAMEG with ARCOP oversight. Need estimation uses data from DSME and GHSC-TA, but limited forecasting capacity affects accuracy. Costing is constrained by exchange rate volatility and budget limits. Supplier selection is based on compliance with standards but limited local supplier capacity creates delays. Contract negotiation is hindered by complex legal clauses and limited expertise. Purchase orders rely on manual systems with error risks. Goods reception occurs at CAMEG warehouses but faces storage and capacity issues. Payments are made by the Ministry of Finance but slowed by verification delays.
bottlenecks: Togo faces bottlenecks including weak inventory traceability, limited forecasting capacity, budget constraints, and delays in contract execution and payment. Root causes include manual systems, limited technical expertise, and fragmented coordination.
quality_assurance: Quality assurance occurs at CAMEG’s warehouse, where goods are inspected before distribution. However, limited warehouse capacity and manual systems weaken QA. Investments in digital inventory systems and training are needed.
innovations: Togo has made progress through AMU expansion, CAMEG centralization of procurement, Global Fund support, and early steps toward digitization of procurement and financial systems.
